#Text=The Story of Weng Cho ; or , the One Devoid of Name
#Text=There was peach-blossom in the orchards of Kien-fi , a blue sky above , and in the air much gladness ; but in Wu Chi ’s yamen gloom hung like the herald of a thunderstorm .

#Text=At one end of a table in the ceremonial hall sat Wu Chi , heaviness upon his brow , deceit in his eyes , and a sour enmity about the lines of his mouth ; at the other end stood his son Weng , and between them , as it were , his whole life lay .

#Text=Wu Chi was an official of some consequence and had two wives , as became him . His union with the first had failed in its essential purpose ; therefore he had taken another to carry on the direct line which alone could bring him contentment in this world and a reputable existence in the next .
#Text=This degree of happiness was supplied by Weng ’s mother , yet she must ever remain but a “ secondary wife , ” with no rights and a very insecure position .
#Text=In the heart of the chief wife smouldered a most bitter hatred , but the hour of her ascendancy came , for after many years she also bore her lord a son .

#Text=Thenceforward she was strong in her authority ; but Weng ’s mother remained , for she was very beautiful , and despite all the arts of the other woman Wu Chi could not be prevailed upon to dismiss her .
#Text=The easy solution of this difficulty was that she soon died -- the “ white powder death ” was the shrewd comment of the inner chambers of Kien-fi .
#Text=Wu Chi put on no mourning , custom did not require it ; and now that the woman had Passed Beyond he saw no necessity to honour her memory at the expense of his own domestic peace .
#Text=His wife donned her gayest robes and made a feast .
#Text=Weng alone stood apart , and in funereal sackcloth moved through the house like an accusing ghost .
#Text=Each day his father met him with a frown , the woman whom alone he must regard as his mother with a mocking smile , but he passed them without any word of dutiful and submissive greeting .
#Text=The period of all seemly mourning ended -- it touched that allotted to a legal parent ; still Weng cast himself down and made no pretence to hide his grief .
#Text=His father ’s frown became a scowl , his mother ’s smile framed a biting word .
#Text=A wise and venerable friend who loved the youth took him aside one day and with many sympathetic words counselled restraint .
#Text=“ For , ” he said , “ your conduct , though affectionate towards the dead , may be urged by the ill-disposed as disrespectful towards the living .
#Text=If you have a deeper end in view , strive towards it by a less open path . ”
#Text=“ You are subtle and esteemed in wisdom , ” replied Weng , “ but neither of those virtues can restore a broken jar .
#Text=The wayside fountain must one day dry up at its source , but until then not even a mountain placed upon its mouth can pen back its secret stores .
#Text=So is it with unfeigned grief . ”

#Text=“ The analogy may be exact , ” replied the aged friend , shaking his head , “ but it is no less truly said : ‘ The wise tortoise keeps his pain inside . ’ Rest assured , on the disinterested advice of one who has no great experience of mountains and hidden springs , but a life-long knowledge of Wu Chi and of his amiable wife , that if you mourn too much you will have reason to mourn more . ”
#Text=His words were pointed to a sharp edge .
#Text=At that moment Wu Chi was being confronted by his wife , who stood before him in his inner chamber .
#Text=“ Who am I ? ” she exclaimed vehemently , “ that my authority should be denied before my very eyes ?
#Text=Am I indeed Che of the house of Meng , whose ancestors wore the Yellow Scabbard , or am I some nameless one ?
#Text=Or does my lord sleep , or has he fallen blind upon the side by which Weng approaches ? ”
#Text=“ His heart is bad and his instincts perverted , ” replied Wu Chi dully .
#Text=“ He ignores the rites , custom , and the Emperor ’s example , and sets at defiance all the principles of domestic government .
#Text=Do not fear that I shall not shortly call him to account with a very heavy call . ”
#Text=“ Do so , my lord , ” said his wife darkly , “ or many valiant champions of the House of Meng may press forward to make a cast of that same account .
#Text=To those of our ancient line it would not seem a trivial thing that their daughter should share her rights with a purchased slave . ”
#Text=“ Peace , cockatrice !

#Text=the woman was well enough , ” exclaimed Wu Chi , with slow resentment . “ But the matter of this obstinacy touches the dignity of my own authority , and before to-day has passed Weng shall bring up his footsteps suddenly before a solid wall . ”
#Text=Accordingly , when Weng returned at his usual hour he found his father awaiting him with curbed impatience .

#Text=That Wu Chi should summon him into his presence in the great hall was of itself an omen that the matter was one of moment , but the profusion of lights before the Ancestral Tablets and the various symbols arranged upon the table showed that the occasion was to be regarded as one involving irrevocable issues .

#Text=“ Weng Cho , ” said his father dispassionately , from his seat at the head of the table , “ draw near , and first pledge the Ancient Ones whose spirits hover above their Tablets in a vessel of wine . ”
